body:
Using `pkg-config` doesn't seem correct to me -- we specifically want to know the include path of the Python we are building for. As an example, consider a Debian machine with a system python installed, and also a hand compiled python. If we just ask `pkg-config`, we'll get the system python, which would be wrong if we're trying to build against our own Python.

How does yocto work with a "normal" setuptools/distutils based process?

Up until this latest change in `40.0.x` we have been able to use some inputs to PyO3 to make cryptography build.

https://git.yoctoproject.org/poky/tree/meta/classes-recipe/python_pyo3.bbclass

Which in turn gets some variable values set in:
https://git.yoctoproject.org/poky/tree/meta/classes-recipe/python3-dir.bbclass

We also use sysconfig:
https://git.yoctoproject.org/poky/tree/meta/classes-recipe/python3targetconfig.bbclass
I guess what I don't understand is how this worked under the previous setup! What was causing a host python to compile+link against a set of headers+libraries besides its own?
This issue has been waiting for a reporter response for 3 days. It will be auto-closed if no activity occurs in the next 5 days.

> Using pkg-config doesn't seem correct to me -- we specifically want to know the include path of the Python we are building for. As an example, consider a Debian machine with a system python installed, and also a hand compiled python. If we just ask pkg-config, we'll get the system python, which would be wrong if we're trying to build against our own Python.

Then you're doing it wrong: if you've build local software and installed into (say) `$HOME/bin` then you put that on `PKG_CONFIG_PATH` before `/usr` and everything _just works_.   Using pkg-config to find software is using the correct tool for the job.

In a cross build the trick is to be sure to use a variable for _what_ pkg-config to use. Default to `pkg-config` but allow the caller to override, for example a triple-prefixed pkg-config binary may know to search into a sysroot automatically.
There's no requirement that a user have placed anything on a `PKG_CONFIG_PATH`. Python works perfectly fine if you simply build it and run the binary.

Sure, but building anything that links to python is a constant source of pain for people who cross-compile (see this ticket).

The fundamental problem is that Python assumes you can run the Python binary that you're building for.  In a cross-compile environment that isn't possible.

Be that as it may, we're not going to fix fundamental issues in Python packaging today :-)

However, if someone can help me understand the answer to:

> I guess what I don't understand is how this worked under the previous setup! What was causing a host python to compile+link against a set of headers+libraries besides its own?

then perhaps we can find a workable solution here.

> However, if someone can help me understand the answer to:
> 
> > I guess what I don't understand is how this worked under the previous setup! What was causing a host python to compile+link against a set of headers+libraries besides its own?
> 
> then perhaps we can find a workable solution here.

> Be that as it may, we're not going to fix fundamental issues in Python packaging today :-)
> 
> However, if someone can help me understand the answer to:
> 
> > I guess what I don't understand is how this worked under the previous setup! What was causing a host python to compile+link against a set of headers+libraries besides its own?
> 
> then perhaps we can find a workable solution here.

I haven't found all the details yet but start with what I found and we can hopefully fill in the unknowns together.

A common start for the old and new versions in Yocto are:

`/work/yocto/poky/build/build-qemuarm64-systemd/tmp/work/core2-64-poky-linux/python3-cryptography/40.0.2-r0/recipe-sysroot-native/usr/bin/python3-native/python3 setup.py bdist_wheel --verbose --dist-dir /work/yocto/poky/build/build-qemuarm64-systemd/tmp/work/core2-64-poky-linux/python3-cryptography/40.0.2-r0/dist`

"-fmacro-prefix-map=/work/yocto/poky/build/build-qemuarm64-systemd/tmp/work/core2-64-poky-linux/python3-cryptography/40.0.2-r0/recipe-sysroot=" "-fdebug-prefix-map=/work/yocto/poky/build/build-qemuarm64-systemd/tmp/work/core2-64-poky-linux/python3-cryptography/40.0.2-r0/recipe-sysroot-native=" "-I" "/usr/include/python3.11" "-I" "/work/yocto/poky/build/build-qemuarm64-systemd/tmp/work/core2-64-poky-linux/python3-cryptography/40.0.2-r0/recipe-sysroot/usr/include" "-Wconversion" "-Wno-error=sign-conversion" "-Wno-unused-parameter" "-DPy_LIMITED_API=0x030600f0" "-o" "/work/yocto/poky/build/build-qemuarm64-systemd/tmp/work/core2-64-poky-linux/python3-cryptography/40.0.2-r0/build/target/x86_64-poky-linux-gnu/release/build/cryptography-rust-692a1fa095ab554f/out/79a447d161ca18d2-_openssl.o" "-c" "/work/yocto/poky/build/build-qemuarm64-systemd/tmp/work/core2-64-poky-linux/python3-cryptography/40.0.2-r0/build/target/x86_64-poky-linux-gnu/release/build/cryptography-rust-692a1fa095ab554f/out/_openssl.c"
```
  cargo:warning=/work/yocto/poky/build/build-qemuarm64-systemd/tmp/work/core2-64-poky-linux/python3-cryptography/40.0.2-r0/build/target/x86_64-poky-linux-gnu/release/build/cryptography-rust-692a1fa095ab554f/out/_openssl.c:57:10: fatal error: Python.h: No such file or directory
  cargo:warning=   57 | #include <Python.h>
  cargo:warning=      |          ^~~~~~~~~~
  cargo:warning=compilation terminated.
  exit status: 1
```
This will add `"-I" "/usr/include/python3.11"` to the compilation.

One difference is that version 40 is building inside a cargo context while version 39 is not doing that. I haven't found how the 'good' path is passed to the build in version 39.

So I think the million dollar question is what causes the compilation of 39 to a) use `x86_64-poky-linux-gcc` as the compiler, and b) add the `-I/work/yocto/poky/build/build-qemuarm64-systemd/tmp/work/core2-64-poky-linux/python3-cryptography-old/39.0.2-r0/recipe-sysroot/usr/include/python3.11` flag (in addition to all of the other flags, of course)

I looked into it as well. I think in 39 the correct include flags are determined by setuptools, whereas in later version there's this newly added bit in src/rust/cryptography-cffi/build.rs:
```
"import sysconfig; print(sysconfig.get_path('include'), end='')",
```
This returns the eventual path on the target device for which we are cross-compiling, but not the sysroot-prefixed path on the build host. I've been able to fix it by replacing with:
```
"import sysconfig; print(sysconfig.get_config_var('INCLUDEPY'), end='')",
```
which returns the right value.

Thank you for diving into this! Are you interested in submitting a PR
to change this?

Can other folks using poky confirm if this fix works for them?

@kanavin - please try this:
```
$ git diff src/rust/build.rs
diff --git a/src/rust/build.rs b/src/rust/build.rs
index 617e5e1..932ce99 100644
--- a/src/rust/build.rs
+++ b/src/rust/build.rs
@@ -51,6 +51,7 @@ fn main() {
     let mut build = cc::Build::new();
     build
         .file(openssl_c)
+        .include("-fPIC")
         .include(python_include)
         .include(openssl_include)
         .flag_if_supported("-Wconversion")
```
I was on this a while ago and from what I remember this solved my compilation with similar issue as you showed above. Unfortunately I was blocked to get this further.
HTH
/Peter

I believe PIC is intended to be on by default:
https://docs.rs/cc/latest/cc/struct.Build.html#method.pic
